title: london house prices no deal brexit latest housing market
story: Created with Sketch.One expert&nbsppredicted house prices could fall by as much as 40 per cent in the event of a disruptive exit from the EUClick to followThe IndependentUK asking prices fell by £7,000 in August, recent figures showedHouse prices in London are set to fall this year and next, and could crash if a no-deal Brexit&nbspoccurs, according to a Reuters poll of property experts and analysts. Respondents predicted prices in the capital will fall 1.6 per cent this year&nbspand 0.1 per cent in 2019, although for the UK in general they are set to rise 2 per cent this year and next, and 2.3 per cent in 2020. The national average price for a property was £301,973 in August, and in London it rose to £609,205. “The weight of evidence suggests that housing is overvalued once more,” said Hansen Lu at Capital Economics.Experts said there was a one in three chance of a “significant correction” in the London market. When asked what effect a disorderly Brexit would have on prices, answers ranged from “short term fall” to “damaging” to “disaster”. When asked about the likelihood of a significant correction in London’s housing market before the end of 2019, the specialists gave a relatively high median of 29 per cent, with the highest response 75 per cent.One respondent predicted house prices could fall by as much as 40 per cent. “We see little upward or downward pressure on house prices at current near-zero interest rates. However&nbsprisks lie substantially to the downside,” said Andrew Brigden, at Fathom Consulting.“Were interest rates to return to pre-crisis levels, or higher – which may prove necessary if there were a sharp fall in sterling after a general election, for example – then house prices could fall by around 40 per cent.”UK house prices should be frozen for five years, think tank saysThis London area has seen the highest 20-year house price growth in UKThe Bank of England recently raised interest rates above 0.5 per cent for the first time since the financial crisis, and said the rate would continue to increase at a gradual pace over the next few years. Survey respondents also noted the weaker pound – sterling fell to a one year low against the euro this week – should be attracting foreign investors to the UK property market, but said uncertainty around Brexit was keeping them away. Recent data from&nbspRightmove showed asking prices in the UK dropped by more than £7,000 in August, due to more sellers arriving on the market.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: frestonia squatters london declare independence uk 1970s free independent
story: Created with Sketch.The Free Independent Republic of Frestonia was born of a generation who knew counterculture as much as precarious living. Now a new book collects photography and stories from the communityClick to followThe IndependentThe community designed a flag, appointed ministers of state – including actor David Rappaport as foreign minister – made their own postage stamps and issued visas for visitorsThere was a lot of talk, in the wake of the Brexit referendum, suggesting that London should stage its own exit from the United Kingdom, declare independence, and ask to rejoin the EU as a nation state.Ignoring for now the fact that not everyone – though&nbspit might seem that way to London – outside the capital voted to leave the EU, it seemed a satisfying, though jokey, postscript to the Brexit vote. Indeed, more than 180,000 Londoners signed an online petition calling for the mayor, Sadiq&nbspKhan, to “declare London independent, and apply to join the EU –&nbspincluding membership of the Schengen zone”.But what a lot of the signatories might not have realised was that there was indeed a precedent for London seceding from the UK. Or at least, one street of the capital.&nbspWelcome to the Free Independent Republic of Frestonia. Or, what’s left of it, which these days amounts to the Frestonian Gallery, keeping the name and spirit alive of one of the most curious episodes in London’s history. It&nbspbegan on Halloween&nbsp1977, when the residents of Freston Road in Notting Dale, West London, which was largely comprised of squats and communes, declared independence.Threatened with eviction, the squatters said they were no longer part of the UK and appealed to the United Nations to send in peacekeeping forces to prevent Greater London Council turfing them out of the homes they had claimed. They designed a flag, appointed ministers of state, and even made their own postage stamps and issued visas for visitors.The short-lived story of the Free Independent Republic of Frestonia has now been documented in a new book of photographs by one of its residents, the photographer Tony Sleep, who was resident on Freston Road from 1974.&nbspSleep describes the Frestonia experiment as “part publicity stunt, part theatrical protest”, and adds that while it wasn’t a serious attempt to break away from the UK, there was never any need to, because what became Frestonia “was already on a different planet”.He writes in the lavish book: “Frestonia was rooted in the counterculture of the time. The period is now dismissed as little more than daft clothes and hair, accompanied by a great soundtrack and the invention of sex and drugs.“It was, we are told, youthful self indulgence that ended badly because it was irresponsible and naive.”Frestonian Gallery)Frestonia was born out of problems that young people will recognise today: the lack of affordable accommodation. Sleep points out that the millennial generation might have a beef with the baby boomers who grew up in the 1960s and 1970s because they had it easy, and accommodation was cheap and plentiful. Not a bit of it, he says.“Rented flats were in very short supply, and mostly slum standard. You might achieve a rented bedsit as long as you weren’t black, Irish&nbspor a dog. Then, as now, landlords wanted ‘professional’ people.“Council housing lists were only for families, and backlogged for decades. Despite what now seem like absurdly low prices, only the wealthy and secure could obtain mortgages at a time before easy mass debts. Less than half the population owned their own homes at the start of the 1970s.”Freston Road, where squatters and activists founded housing coop and community Frestonia&nbsp(Getty)Many of the houses on Freston Road were empty, having been condemned as unfit for human habitation, and most of the residents had been relocated to the new highrise blocks of flats that began to go up in the 1960s and 1970s. There had been a move to demolish the vacant properties, but residents in neighbouring communities had complained that they would be looking out onto swathes of barren, rubble-strewn land that would encourage flytipping, so the authorities decided to take the cheaper option and just leave the buildings standing for a while.Freston Road might have been abandoned, but that didn’t mean it was unused. From 1974, squatters began to break into the empty houses and set up home there Tony Sleep, aged 24 at that time, was one of them.He recalls:&nbsp“Squatting is distinctly equal opportunity. If you can gain possession, it’s yours. This led to an interesting mix of people who had little in common except needing somewhere to live and being poor for one reason or another. While some tried to make their new homes habitable, several houses were quickly wrecked.”Sleep remembers well his first sight of Freston Road. He’d been living in a “dismal rented basement” in west Kensington, but as he and his girlfriend parted company, he needed somewhere else to live, and heard about a street of empty houses. Some of his friends went to have a look and broke into two of the houses.“That night I paid them a visit,” writes Sleep. “Eight people, four guys, four girls, in one candlelit room, the only one that had windows. There was no toilet, no water, no electricity.”But his friends set to work installing plumbing and wiring as best they could, found an old toilet, rescued carpets and furniture from skips, and Sleep asked if he could move in with them.By 1977 Freston Road had settled into an unorthodox community, of sorts. But the attention of the GLC wandered back to these old, abandoned homes, and the squatters were told that they were to be evicted from these properties.The council offered to place the squatters in what were considered “hard to let” properties dotted around London, and some took the flats –&nbspand, says Sleep, were promptly replaced in Freston Road by other people desperate for somewhere to live.&nbspThe GLC announced its intention to bulldoze Freston Road after all, and a meeting was called, attended by 200 people. They decided – inspired by the Ealing comedy Passport to Pimlico – to go it alone. The Free Independent Republic of Frestonia was born. And the battle was on.The Frestonian National Anthem was written (“Long live Frestonia! Land of the free – not the GLC”) and a community newspaper, The Tribal Messenger, was distributed. Frestonia made the international press, and the Daily Mirror ran a piece declaring “All Hall, Frestonia”. The actor David Rappaport was made foreign minister, and playwright Heathcote Williams became ambassador to the United Kingdom.It was all a bit jolly and, of course, more than a pinch of Ealing comedy. But, Sleep points out, Frestonia was also an interesting way of putting British society under the&nbspmicroscope.“Communities are defined, more or less, by what people have in common,” he writes. “That’s usually class, background or aspiration, sometimes race or religion. What people have in common helps them feel safe and valued. What is different can be threatening or isive.Frestonian Gallery)“Families, on the other hand, are a matter of being stuck with people you sometimes struggle to tolerate, let alone like. Frestonia was a bit of both.“Frestonians were, beneath the veneer of pragmatic anarchy, from different cultures. There were the hippies, idealists of a sort. There were the punks, nihilists of a sort. And there were the itinerant street people, whose lack of youth and lost changes gave them a thread of bitterness to chew on together.”Over the next couple of years, fighting the threat of the GLC bulldozers, the anarchic squat collective organised itself more seriously, forming the Bramley Housing Cooperative with an aim that was less about the fun of independence and more about securing the future of the Freston Road community.Eventually, the GLC won the war, and demolition of the squats began in 1983. But the Bramley Housing Cooperative, working with the Notting Hill Housing Trust, continued to fight for Freston Road as a residential area. And, ultimately, they won.Sleep says, “Frestonia didn’t cease when the squats were demolished. How could it? They were only useful ruins. Frestonia was about the people, its improbable family.“If you walk through Frestonia now, there’s little to suggest it is much different from anywhere else. You’ll find a street of small, but perhaps unusually pretty houses, built in the mid 1980s. They look carefully designed, a bit too inidual to be social housing. You may not notice the enclosed communal gardens, or the sheltered housing scheme that the coop insisted on, you won’t know the coop ensured housing for some of the more vulnerable Frestonians.”It might be that Frestonia would be forgotten all together, but for Tony Sleep’s photographic record of the people, events and houses on Freston Road in the late 1970s and early 1980s.‘Pop-up squat’: Activists occupy property to protest Housing BillNew photography exhibition shows the tough reality of squattingChallenging consumption and overwork in a Danish communityThe name does linger on in the form of the Frestonian Gallery, opened in 2017 by Matt Incledon and Rollo Campbell, who have published Tony Sleep’s photographs and recollections in Welcome To Frestonia. A pair of, in their own words, “itinerant art dealers”, they opened the gallery in The People’s Hall, a Victorian building that was once at the heart of Frestonia.&nbspFrestonian Gallery opened in 2017 to remember a most curious episode in London’s history&nbsp(Tony SleepFrestonian Gallery)Becoming appraised of the story of Frestonia, they were introduced to Tony Sleep, and arranged an exhibition of his photographs. They write in their foreword: “It was an exhibition unlike anything either of us had worked on previously. Each day at the gallery provided a steady stream of visitors keen to revisit and share their own personal memories of Frestonia. It would be a nice point at which to say ‘We then decided a book of Tony’s work needs to be published...’ but again, in truth, the decision had been made for us already by the sheer emotional response to this unique exhibition.”Was it all worth it for the Frestonians? Did it make a difference? Tony Sleep closes his remarkable document of this time by musing, “Forty years on, the UK seems to have travelled in a large circle and arrived little the wiser, but probably angrier, more cynical and more ided than ever.&nbspWe are all Frestonians, on this small blue dot in the middle of nowhere. We are all one family, whether we like it or not.”Welcome to Frestonia by Tony Sleep&nbspis published by the Frestonian Gallery (frestoniangallery), priced £35Free Independent Republic of FrestoniaEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: pound sterling dollar exchange rates brexit deal michel barnier
story: Created with Sketch.The EU's chief negotiator said the bloc is ready for a no-deal BrexitClick to followThe IndependentMr Barnier back-tracked somewhat on optimistic remarks from WednesdayThe pound&nbspdropped against the dollar on Wednesday, falling back from gains made off the back of optimist Brexit outlooks offered by both EU and British negotiators on Tuesday. Sterling fell by as much as 0.3 per cent against the dollar&nbspafter the EU’s chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said in a German radio interview that the bloc is prepared for a no-deal Brexit. “After the sterling bounce yesterday,&nbspBarnier has used a German radio interview this morning to remind the market that the EU is also planning for a no-deal scenario,” Jeremy Stretch at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, told Bloomberg.“This suggests they are not intent on a deal at all costs and that sterling gains may prove tough to hold onto.”The pound was boosted on Tuesday, rising 1.2 per cent against the dollar, and 1 per cent against the euro, after Mr Barnier said the EU is “prepared to offer a partnership with Britain such as has never been with any other third country. His positive remarks came as Brexit secretary Dominic Raab told the Lords EU committee that he was “confident a deal is within our sights”“We're bringing ambition, pragmatism, energy and if, and I expect it will be, and if it is matched, we get a deal,” he said. Hussein Sayed, chief market strategist at FXTM, said many investors would be wondering whether Mr Barnier’s positive statement on Wednesday could be a turning point for the pound. “Although many issues related to trade and the Irish border are far from being resolved, it currently seems that negotiations may begin moving in the right direction. However, expect volatility to surge in the coming weeks as we get closer to the Brexit deadline,” he said.The pound remained up against the euro, trading up 0.02 per cent at €1.1128 by mid-morning.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: snapchat new york jewtropolis snap map
story: Created with Sketch.Snapchat users reported that New York had been renamed to Jewtropolis on Snap MapSnacpchat blamed third party mapping data from its partner MapboxClick to followThe Independent TechNew York has been renamed Jewtropolis within Snapchat's Snap Map feature, after online vandals were apparently able to take it over.Snap Map is designed to allow users to discover content within specific regions across the world, such as Snaps of sporting events, celebrations and breaking news.It uses software provided by&nbspMapbox, a separate company that provides custom maps for applications including Foursquare and Lonely Planet. According to&nbspSnapchat, this software was the victim of vandalism.Thanks for bringing this to our attention. Snap Map relies on third party mapping data which has unfortunately been subject to vandalism, the&nbspSnapchat&nbspSupport account on Twitter responded to a user who shared a screenshot of the map.We are working with our partner Mapbox to get this fixed immediately.Snapchat was not the only company to be affected by the issue. Users of&nbsp the apps Jump Bike, StreetEasy amd Zillow also reported seeing New York renamed to Jewtropolis.The change has since been fixed by Mapbox, who said the issue was resolved on Thursday morning.A spokesperson for Mapbox was not immediately available for comment, however CEO Eric Gunderson told Tech Crunch that the fault lay with his company.Mr Gunderson added that the company was still investigating the incident.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: china uighur muslims re education camps detention xinjiang
story: Created with Sketch.Human rights experts received reports around a million Uighurs&nbspare held in what resembles a 'massive internment camp that is shrouded in secrecy'Click to followThe IndependentFormer detainee claims Muslims in re-education camps were forced to eat pork and drink alcoholChina must release Uighur Muslims from alleged re-education camps 'immediately', UN saysChina must immediately release Uighur&nbspMuslims being held in alleged political re-education camps on the “pretext of countering terrorism”, a committee of UN human rights experts have said.Up to one million Uighurs, a largely Muslim minority, may be held involuntarily in extra-legal detention in China’s far western Xinjiang province, according to estimates cited by the committee.A former inmate in one of the interment camps said Muslims were forced to eat pork and drink alcohol, acts which are forbidden by their religion.The UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination&nbspissued its findings after a two-day review of China’s record, the first since 2009, earlier this month.China’s foreign ministry rejected the allegations at the time, and said anti-China forces were behind the criticism of Beijing’s policies in Xinjiang.It has never officially confirmed the existence of detention centres there.China has said Xinjiang faces a serious threat from Islamist militants and separatists who plot attacks and stir up tensions between the Uighur&nbspminority and the ethnic Han Chinese majority.The panel criticised China’s “broad definition of terrorism and vague references to extremism and unclear definition of separatism in Chinese legislation”.It said the definition could be used against those peacefully exercising their rights and facilitates “criminal profiling” of ethnic and religious minorities, including Uighurs, Buddhist Tibetans and Mongolians.In its conclusions, the panel said it was alarmed by&nbsp“numerous reports of detention of large numbers of ethnic Uighurs and other Muslim minorities held incommunicado and often for long periods, without being charged or tried, under the pretext of countering terrorism and religious extremism”.Chinese officials did not immediately comment on the panel’s criticism.&nbsp&nbspWorld news in picturesFirefighters watch on as flames leap from a giant factory fire in the inner Melbourne suburb of West Footscray - title: nick knowles claims finding camelot round table history archeology
story: A Roman amphitheatre in Gloucestershire  (Image: Francis Hawkins)The town was once only behind London in importance and size and boasted one of the biggest Roman amphitheatres in the country.&nbspDIY SOS presenter Nick, 55, said: &ldquoMe and a professor at Bristol University reckon Camelot is in Cirencester &ndash and we can prove it.&nbsp&ldquoSo the story about King Arthur having a table where 5,000 knights could sit without precedence comes from the circular amphitheatre. That&rsquos where King Arthur had his round table.&nbspNick claimed King Arthur may have placed the table in the middle of the amphitheatre.&nbsp                King Arthur birthplace: Stone inscriptions could 'prove' legend was...It could hold 8,000 spectators before the Roman army left Britain in around AD 408 and is believed to have fallen to the Saxons around AD 577.&nbspProfessor Mark Horton, of the University of Bristol, said: &ldquoThe most likely place to be Camelot is where the Roman way of life survived the longest.&nbsp&ldquoThat is in this area of western Britain and Cirencester is the capital. There is also the archaeology from the amphitheatre. When it was investigated by local archaeologists in the 1960s, a series of post holes were found.&ldquoThis is very significant. It suggests it had a second use, maybe as a headquarters of a king.&nbspNick Knowles (Image: WireImage)&ldquoEach of the different parts of the UK in Roman times had its own ruler and it is the most conceivable context for Arthur. &ldquoThe amphitheatre might be a reference to the round table.&nbspMr Knowles met Professor Horton while searching for details about the first English colony in North America.&nbspProf Horton added: &ldquoThe story of King Arthur and Camelot and the Round Table is one of the foundations of Britain.

title: new centrist party United for Change splits Brexit Simon Franks Adam Knight
story: Simon Franks, co-founder of United for Change, is reported to have secured a &pound50million investment (Image: Simon Franks)A new centrist party called United for Change has lost its chief executive ahead of its launch, scheduled for next year, who has left to form his own splinter party.United for Change, which is reported to have attracted &pound50million worth of investment, declared itself as an &ldquoalternative to the isive and extremist politics we see at Westminster.Former chief executive Adam Knight, who also co-founded the party, has taken some of his staff with him after disagreements over tactics and is provisionally calling his rival party Twelve Together, a reference to the twelve UK regions.He said: &ldquoIn the end United for Change considered two potential strategic directions.                Nick Robinson roasts Lib Dems Peer on new centrist anti-Brexit party                Remainers to launch NEW party to take us BACK into the EU after Brexit&ldquoThe first was to take advantage of political instability surrounding Brexit to launch a political party around which the public, and maybe parliamentarians, could congregate as quickly as the beginning of 2019, whilst the second was to take a longer look at what it might mean to develop a new type of political organisation.&ldquoWe tried for a while to see if the two approaches could coexist, but it became clear that, while overlapping in places, they represented a fundamentally different style of leadership, set of values, timeline, and programme of activity.&ldquoWe decided in the end the best thing to do would be for United for Change to focus on launching next year, with another group looking a the potential for a long-term approach.Mr Knight co-founded United for Change with Simon Franks, an entrepreneur who set up LoveFilm, who is said to have brought in the huge financial investment, as well as putting in a seven-figure sum himself.One senior politician on Simon Franks:  &ldquoHe appears to think he can be Britain&rsquos answer to Macron (Image: )Leading Labour opponents of Jeremy Corbyn, like Chuka Umunna, have distanced themselves from the venture and other MPs have questioned Mr Franks&rsquos motives, some suggesting his aim is just to advance his own political career.One senior politician said: &ldquoHe appears to think he can be Britain&rsquos answer to Emmanuel Macron.Mr Knight meanwhile, who is an Anglo-Canadian banker with Credit Suisse, dabbled in politics before when he ran as an independent in the Witney by-election following David Cameron&rsquos departure from the Commons.He still emphasised the shared goal he had with party he left behind, saying: &ldquoI think everyone in United for Change shared the same diagnosis of the issue, which is that the status quo is essentially broken and no longer works for the majority of the country.                Brexit News: Lord Adonis blasts plan to imitate Macron in the UK                Vince Cable 'secret talks' over new ANTI-BREXIT political partySince the European Referendum, there have been a number of new pro-EU centrist parties set up (Image: )&ldquoIn the absence of existing systems doing what they need to do there needs to be change - and change needs to involve new people and new approaches.&ldquoEveryone&rsquos aware that the barriers to entry are formidable and the team spent a lot of time trying to play a path which might be able to challenge the status quo.Since the Brexit referendum, there have been a number of different pro-EU parties set up.Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable recently received criticism for missing a key Brexit vote in Parliament, because he was attending a meeting to discuss a new centrist party.

story: The Queen has a secret hobby she does only once a year (Image: Getty)The official Royal website recently revealed Queen Elizabeth is passionate about Scottish country dancing.According to the site, the 92-year-old Royal hosts dances for neighbours, Castle staff and members of the community every year at Balmoral castle.A video from 1990 has emerged showing the Queen dancing the Eightsome Reel, a Scottish country dance, with Prince Philip, Princess Anne, Prince Charles and the Queen mother at Balmoral.The Queen&rsquos annual dancing events are known as Ghillies Balls.                Why Princess Charlotte might lose her royal title when she gets older                 Kate won&rsquot have a MAJESTIC coronation ceremony for THIS reasonThe Official Royal website reads: &ldquoThe Queen takes a keen and highly knowledgeable interest in horses.&ldquoThe Queen also enjoys walking in the countryside and spending time with her dogs.&ldquoA lesser known interest is Scottish country dancing.&ldquoEach year during her stay at Balmoral Castle, The Queen gives dances known as Ghillies' Balls, for neighbours, estate and Castle staff and members of the local community.The Queen&rsquos annual dancing events are known as Ghillies Balls (Image: Getty)The monarch has been reported to be a fantastic dancer, as Lady Elizabeth Arson praised her for her great rhythm in the BBC documentary Our Queen: 90 Musical Years.Lady Elizabeth Anson said: The Queen loves the theatre and musicals like Showboat, Oklahoma! and Annie Get Your Gun.These were the tunes that remained in one's head and were very danceable to.The Queen is a fantastic dancer. She's got great rhythm. story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will attend a gala concert in Westminster next week (Image: Getty)The gala evening of music is presented by the Royal Armouries and it will mark the centenary of the last 100 days of First World War hostilities.It will take place on Thursday, September 6, at Central Hall Westminster.Prices start at &pound49.95 and all the proceeds will go to three charities: Help for Heroes, Combat Stress and Heads Together.All three charities support military veterans suffering from mental health conditions, which is a cause known to be really close to Prince Harry.                Meghan Markle carried out SECRET trip to Toronto to see her friend                Meghan Markle teased Prince Harry at Hamilton performanceFor a limited time there is also a 2-for-1 offer on tickets to the concert for the public, which is available only when booking through Ticketmaster.Ex-army chief General Lord Dannatt said about the concert: &ldquoWe are delighted to welcome The Duke and Duchess of Sussex to the Central Hall Westminster for this commemorative event.&ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the support shown by our sponsors, ambassadors and all three beneficiary charities.The highlight of the evening&rsquos programme will be Sir Karl Jenkins conducting his internationally acclaimed work The Armed Man: A Mass for Peace, performed by the Royal Choral Society and the Philharmonia Orchestra.                The moment Charles ROLLS EYES at Diana night before their wedding                Queen Elizabeth has a SECRET hobby she does only once a year Last week the newlywed royals went to see Hamilton, an awarding winning theatre performance (Image: Getty)This will be the only performance of &lsquoThe Armed Man&rsquo in England in 2018 to be conducted by Sir Karl himself.The gala concert will be the second event Meghan and Harry attend in less than two weeks, as only last Wednesday the newlywed royals went to see Hamilton, an awarding winning theatre performance.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex sat with the audience in the royal circle at the Victoria Palace Theatre in London for the popular show.When the hit musical ended, Prince Harry even sang the start of a Hamilton song which was once performed by the actor playing his ancestor King George III, the Royal&rsquos sixth-great-grandfather.When the hit musical ended, Prince Harry even sang the start of a Hamilton song  (Image: Getty)The Duke of Sussex began to sing &ldquoYou say.. from the song &lsquoYou&rsquoll Be Back&rsquo before he stopped and said to the cast &ldquoYou did try, but I said no.The event raised &pound300,000, which will be used to improve the lives of children affected by HIV in Africa.Meghan looked stunning in a short &pound327 Judith and Charles tuxedo dress for the show.She had already seen the show in Broadway, New York with her friend Priyanka Chopra.

title: Brexit news Rees Mogg Lord Adonis UK EU withdrawal second referendum vote latest
story: Lord Adonis blasted the leading Brexiteer after a 2016 video emerged of Jacob Rees-Mogg calling for Irish border controls as we had during the troubles.In a scathing attack of the Tory backbencher, Lord Adonis suggested supporters of Mr Rees-Mogg are extremists pressuring the Government into a hard Brexit.Speaking to BBC Foyle, the Labour peer said: Jacob Rees-Mogg speaks for about the 10 percent most extreme part of the Conservative Party, which is a tiny fraction of the House of Commons.The problem we&rsquove got is this 10 percent of extremists are the tail wagging the dog at the moment. They&rsquove got Theresa May in their grip, they keep threatening to call leadership elections.                'France must EXPEL the English!' French fishermen threaten UK Lord Adonis, who quit his Government post as head of National Infrastructure Commission to fight Brexit, branded as mind-boggling suggestions to reinstitute border patrols once Britain leaves the European Union.He continued: The idea that we should regard as a precedent for how we handle the big problem we&rsquod have about massive smuggling across the border, the idea that we regard as a precedent for those border guards in the Troubles is mind-boggling.What we&rsquove got is a policy of a Government which is being dictated by extremists. In Northern Ireland, you know only too well what it&rsquos like to have policy dictated by extremists.He added: You might think it&rsquos a joke and somehow reason will prevail and everything will be ok but I can assure that doesn&rsquot always happen. That&rsquos why I think Jacob Rees-Mogg is a very dangerous and threatening force.Brexit news: Lord Adonis said Mr Rees-Mogg is a  (Image: )Responding to Lord Adonis' comments, Mr Rees-Mogg told Express: It is a rather peculiar view, all I want is for the Brexit people voted for to take place.This is not an extreme view but One held by the bulk of the country according to opinion polls.It is a matter for pity that some remainers are so emotionally attached to the EU that they cannot reconcile themselves to the referendum result&rsquo.The 2016 video shows Mr Rees-Mogg advocating for inspections on people crossing the Irish border. While shared widely on social media over the past few days, it appears to have been recorded in the run-up to the Brexit referendum.Brexit news: Rees-Mogg said it was matter of pity for Remainers to be emotionally attached to EU (Image: )The Irish border, which zig-zags for more than 300 miles across the north-east of Ireland and is crossed by 200 public roads, has been the biggest issue facing Britain as it leaves the EU.During the Troubles, the period of civil unrest in Ireland during the late-20th century, major border crossings were blocked by British Army checkpoints, with some smaller routes closed completely.Fears of a return to a hard border and a return to bloodshed have grown since England and Wales voted to leave the EU in June 2016. Northern Ireland, like Scotland, voted heavily in favour of Remain.The British Government remains unable to explain how cross-border trade and the movement of goods will continue after Brexit without the establishment of customs checkpoints or even CCTV cameras - which would constitute a hard border, a red line issue for Dublin, Belfast and Brussels.

title: Brexit news Jack Brereton Michel Barnier deal uk eu withdrawal trade latest
story: Stock-on-Trent MP Jack Brereton suggested that EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is unlikely to agree to any deal that would see the creation of new tariff barriers with the UK after Brexit.Mr Brereton told Express in June that EU member states will not want unnecessary tariffs that could harm their trade.He said: We have still got some way to go and the next stage is particularly the economic and trade elements of that. I think we will come to a stage where we get an effective trade policy around that.We must also consider the fact that it&rsquos not just that the UK doesn&rsquot want to have unnecessary tariffs on trade. Those European countries will not want to have unnecessary and ineffective tariffs on trade because it will hit them just as much as they would hit us.                Brexit news: Farage warns don't fall for Barnier's 'FORKED tongue'Mr Brereton remained confident Britain and the bloc will be able to strike a new arrangement in the time left to negotiate which would also ensure no hard border is created in Northern Ireland.He continued: We do want to maintain those economic links with the European Union, have that frictionless trade and I think there are ways of achieving that.We don&rsquot want that hard border with Northern Ireland, but we don&rsquot want a hard border along the Irish Channel either.&nbspCertainly, we can do that and achieve that through means of technology, introducing more effective technology at borders.I think that would be a really good way to ensure that it isn&rsquot so burdensome of the measures that we introduce.Brexit news: Jack Brereton said EU countries do not want  (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bull)Mr Barnier announced on Wednesday Brussels is prepared to offer London a deal like no other third country in an unexpected move after the start of the last phase of withdrawal talks.The Frenchman stressed the UK and EU are entering the final stages of the negotiations and have to be very careful because the last phase is very sensitive and difficult.He affirmed that Theresa May's commitment to an Irish backstop, insisting it must be part of any withdrawal agreement.Mr Barnier added: In addition to the agreement, we must publish in October or November a very important political declaration on the future relationship, that we want with the UK to be as close as possible.The EU's chief negotiator is set to meet Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab on Friday after reports that UK officials are growing frustrated at the lack of time the EU negotiator is affording them during the talks.

story: Wolfgang Fink, CEO for Germany and Austria at Goldman Sachs, said preparations for Brexit are &ldquoin full swing &ndash insisting that the global financial services company will be ready for any Brexit outcome.Mr Fink told CNBC: &ldquoYou will see, as we moving closer to March 29, that we are getting way more closer in terms of tangible actions that we have to take. That includes putting up the infrastructure.&ldquoThat includes, obviously, all the adjacent projects which we have to run in parallel. So, while we as Goldman still think that if you can get a transition period we would have more time to do it more diligent, to work more on those topics.&ldquoWe are prepared to be ready on March 29 &ndash preparations are in full swing.                UK will NOT benefit from EU after Brexit - warns France minister                May told to SCRAP Chequers for &lsquoCanada plus-plus&rsquo Brexit dealHe added: &ldquoIn terms of activities and people that we will have to move to the continent. I think the numbers are obviously fluctuating but we think around 500 people will move to the continent and a large part of that will go to Frankfurt.When asked about his response to the political uncertainty within the&nbspEuropean Union, he said: &ldquoI think the uncertainties you talk about&nbspshow&nbspus how important the European project is and how important it is to get it working.&ldquoGet it working in many aspects for the financial industry to get a strong Europe, to get not only a strong finance for Frankfurt but also to get a strong European capital market to get strong European banks.&ldquoSo I think the challenges we are facing is a wake-up call for everybody who thought it&rsquos an option.Brexit news: Wolfgang Fink said it is a necessity to support EU project (Image: &bullCNBC)&ldquoI think it&rsquos a necessity given the environment we are in.French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire warned on Wednesday that the UK will not be able to reap the benefits of being in the EU when it leaves the bloc.Mr Le Maire said both sides are keen to avoid a hard Brexit but the UK should not benefit from the EU when it leaves.The 49-year-old said: &ldquoYou cannot be out of the European construction, out of the European continent, and also benefiting of all the advantages of being a full member of the European Union.President Emmanuel Macron&rsquos ally added: &ldquoWe are all willing to avoid a hard Brexit. I&rsquom convinced that it is the interests of the UK and all European countries to pave the way for a good compromise between the UK and European countries.Theresa May's Government has published technical notices on the preparations being done for the prospect of a no-deal Brexit.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab says he believes a deal is &ldquowithin our sights.He said: &ldquoWe're bringing ambition, pragmatism, energy and if, and I expect it will be, and if it is matched, we get a deal.

title: Brexit news update Steven Woolfe Anna Soubry Twitter clash latest
story: In a video published on his Youtube Channel, the former Ukip politician attacked the Tory Remainer as she accused hard Brexiteers joining the Conservative Party of trying to topple Theresa May's leadership.&nbspMr Woolfe pointed out the Tory MP's hypocrisy, claiming she had been opposing the Government's policy on Brexit since the 2017 election.In the video, he said: &ldquoLooking across newspapers you can see there is fear running through Conservative Remainers such as Anna Soubry about the so-called Blue Momentum infiltration of the Conservative Party.&ldquoWell, I&rsquom not sure what they mean by Blue Momentum or the infiltration of the Conservative Party.                'Remainers are NOT LISTENING' Brexit heavyweights HIT BACK at EU ex...Brexit news: Anna Soubry and Steven Woolfe clash on Twitter (Image: STEVEN WOOLFE&bullUK PARLIAMENT)&ldquoBut what I do see are thousands of people across the country who have Conservative values with a small C who believe in Brexit are saying &lsquowe need to have our voice heard&rsquo.&ldquoAnd they&rsquore joining the Conservative Party because they&rsquore the only party that can deliver it if there was the right leadership and belief.&ldquoBut of course there are those in the Conservative Party who vehemently oppose ever leaving the European Union.&ldquoAnd if we do, they want us as tied to it as strongly as possible and making us as weak as possible going forward.&ldquoAnd one of those is Anna Soubry.On Thursday, Ms Soubry criticised Leavers willing to join the Conservative Party, claiming they&nbspwould only do so with the intention to challenge Mrs May's leadership.&nbspBrexit news: Steven Woolfe's tweet against Remoaner Anna Soubry (Image: TWITTER)She said: &ldquoHard Brexiteers are trying to sign up to the Tories in order to topple the leader and destroy Government policy.Mr Woolfe hit back at the Remainer's comment accusing her of being a hypocrite.&nbspThe British MEP said: &ldquoI think that was a bit of &lsquopot calling kettle black&rsquo if you ask me.&ldquoBecause how many times as it seemed that Anna Soubry has gone against the Government&rsquos position on leaving the European Union?&ldquoIsn&rsquot it what they said in the election in 2017?&ldquoIsn&rsquot it what they voted for when they voted to leave in Parliament?&ldquoShe has been against Government policy ever since the election of 2017.Brexit news: Anna Soubry tweets back at Steven Woolfe (Image: TWITTER)The clash&nbspescalated on Twitter when Mr Woolfe posted his video with the caption: Remoaner @Anna_Soubry is a hypocrite. Former SDP member, she joined the Conservatives in the 80s, and now wants the Tories to reject new members. The @Conservatives should be embracing this &lsquoBlue Momentum&rsquo and welcoming proper conservatives.And again, in response to a Twitter user claiming a proper politician would not resort to insults and hyperboles, Mr Woolfe wrote: Yeah I know, @Anna_Soubry referred to me as a &lsquobugger&rsquo and a &lsquobastard&rsquo in a debate with her.But Anna Soubry hit back at the prominent Brexiteer and insisted he had his facts wrong.The Tory MP then denied she had insulted him in a debate and called fellow Remainer Lord Adonis to her aid.Ms Soubry tweeted: This man doesn&rsquot do facts eg: I joined the @conservatives in the 70&rsquos and I was a never a member of the SDP (I did however join the Liberals when I was 17) and I think @Andrew_Adonis has a better memory of who called who what in that particular debate!

story: The LBC caller warned that Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has been surrounded by &ldquoBlairite europhiles who want to thwart Brexit.The Brexit-supporting radio caller claimed a Labour Government must get in power or risk the Conservative Party selling out on the NHS.The Brexit debate was sparked by the radio caller saying he &ldquosympathises with eurosceptic Frank Field, who resigned the Labour whip on Thursday to serve as an independent Labour MP.Ron insisted Mr Field needs to do the &ldquodemocratic thing and stand for a by-election.                Brexiteer MEP in fiery Twitter clash with 'hypocrite' Remoaner Soubry                Awkward Boris Johnson moment as Kenyan president FORGETS his nameMr Field has been a consistent supporter of Brexit and has criticised the Labour Party for attacking people concerned about immigration.Mr Field has long been a controversial Labour MP because of his conservative stance on certain issues.A spokesman for Mr Corbyn told the Press Association: Frank has been looking for an excuse to resign for some time.They added that it was not possible to resign as a Labour MP and remain a member of the Labour Party.A Labour Party spokesman also said: Jeremy Corbyn thanks Frank Field for his service to the Labour Party.Mr Field has faced criticism from party members for his voting record on key Government Brexit legislation.Last month he faced a vote of no confidence from his local party.

story: Speaking to CNBC, the portfolio manager at Conning Asia Pacific said the UK financial services may have an opening to gain a foothold in China post-Brexit.Mr Franklin explained how China recently expressed its will to relinquish control over foreign ownership of financial entities.&nbspThis would give UK firms to partner up with Chinese businesses while retaining full non-EU dependent control over the terms of new financial deals.He said: &ldquoThe UK&rsquos economy has been driven by the service&rsquos sector, through financial and non-financial services, over the last few years.                EU will offer special Brexit deal &ldquoAnd China recently, interestingly, has talked about relinquishing certain controls over foreign ownership of the financial entities in China.&ldquoSo that might be an opening for UK financial service businesses to gain a foothold in China and partner with local players but retaining control in terms of the proposition they&rsquore offering to prospective clients.Last Friday,&nbspChina&rsquos Commerce Minister&nbspZhong Shan confirmed Britain is one step closer to securing a &ldquotop notch free trade agreement with China after exiting the European Union.The good news was announced after talks between Trade Secretary Liam Fox and his Chinese counterpart.Brexit news: Expert claims UK will have an opening to gain financial foothold in China post-Brexit (Image: &bullCNBC)Britain has pushed a strong message to Chinese companies that it will be open for business after leaving the EU in March 2019 and that China is one of the countries it wants to sign a free trade deal with.As tensions of a trade war have continued to escalate between the US and China, the Prime Minister has seen this as an opportunity to boost Britain&rsquos Brexit ambitions.On Friday, Zhong Shan in Beijing said the two countries discussed how to boost investment and expand trade in services.&nbspHe added without giving details that the two countries also agreed to actively explore the possibility of discussing a top notch free trade agreement between the two sides after Brexit.Formal talks cannot begin until the UK officially leaves the EU, but this step could give the UK added confidence and leverage in negotiations with the EU.Free trade talks also typically take years to conclude.&nbspMr Zhong also said he hoped that Britain would use the opportunity of a major import fair in November in Shanghai, which President Xi Jinping is overseeing, to expand its exports to China.Dr Fox will lead Britain&rsquos delegation in November to the import fair along with Prince Andrew.The Trade Secretary said his goal is to boost exports to 35 percent of the gross domestic product after leaving the EU.

story: The revelation has led to the admission that Brussels has no &ldquoplan B to cope with the chaos of the UK exiting the EU without a deal.A deficit of up to &pound12.7billion a year could result from the UK&rsquos departure from the EU next March, influential German commissioner Mr Oettinger was forced to admit.As a result, he cautioned, the Brussels machine was scrambling to plug the vast financial chasm left by Brexit.Speaking at an event in Brussels, Mr Oettinger said: &ldquoOur expectation is the UK is willing to fulfil all obligations of an existing MFF which was accepted by David Cameron.                Theresa May and Philip Hammond' fight over new 10p plastic bags                 Jamie Oliver blames BREXIT for struggle to keep restaurants afloat &ldquoWe are optimistic the Brits are willing to fulfil these obligations and use these rights and we have for the moment no reason to develop a plan B.On whether he expected the UK to honour the &pound39billion Brexit bill in the event of no deal, Mr Oettinger revealed there &ldquonever ever was a destructive intervention from the UK&rsquos side in the talks.He added: So we have for the moment no reason to expect a totally different position in the next days, weeks or months.The German eurocrat, who is close to Chancellor Angela Merkel, expects the UK and EU to agree a &ldquosmart Brexit.EU bosses want Michel Barnier to thrash out a deal with the UK (Image: )Mr Oettinger revealed there &ldquonever ever was a destructive intervention from the UK&rsquos side (Image: )Mr Oettinger said Brussels was scrambling to plug the vast financial chasm left by Brexit (Image: )He said: &ldquoNo doubt it&rsquos a polar game at this moment, and there are different interests. But in our EU27 I know nobody who would prefer a hard Brexit.&ldquoWe have to do our best to defend and to bring our legal and financial and political arguments but not to come to a worst case scenario.The European Commission is demanding more money from EU member states to maintain current spending levels without its second largest net contributor - the UK.But the remaining 27 nations are bitterly ided over the size of its forecasted seven-year budget, known as a Multi-Annual Financial Framework.A selection of states, centred around the Netherlands, Austria and Sweden, argue the budget should be reduced to reflect the UK&rsquos departure next March.                Expat warning: No deal Brexit could see pensions STOPPED                EU WILL LOSE: May vows to deliver Brexit despite Chequers backlashMr Raab gave a speech last week detailing the Government's contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit (Image: )The bloc is working alongside its chief negotiator Michel Barnier to implore him to thrash out a deal with the UK so that we continue to contribute to the EU&rsquos purse, Mr Oettinger ulged.The German&rsquos comments about his desire to avoid a hard Brexit come after Swedish foreign minister Annika Soder said the bloc was still holding out for the UK to change its mind and remain in the EU.Speaking at a meeting in Vienna, she argued it would be a &ldquogood idea for the UK to halt Brexit talks now and remain in the club.She said: &ldquoYou know that we wanted to keep you and we look at the polls and we see there may be some hesitation.The Government is releasing more than 80 papers outlining its plans for a no-deal outcome (Image: )We hope we can find a way forward to have a soft Brexit because a hard Brexit wouldn&rsquot serve anyone.We won't give up on a soft Brexit even if that tiny hope is still there.&ldquoBut still, and this may be not very polite, we hope there will be a solution where the UK will still be in the EU.The Swedish politician refused to endorse a second Brexit referendum saying it was not her place to interfere.But she added: &ldquoFor the EU, if we look at our perspective and the Swedish perspective, of course, we would want to have the UK as a partner.

title: UK weather forecast hot Met Office latest heat September 2018 long range forecast
story: High pressure stretching from the tropical Azores Islands will pull a pulse of warm air in from the south bringing a late blast of summer.The mercury will rise into the mid 20Cs this weekend despite Saturday marking the start of the meteorological autumn.It will turn gradually warmer through the start of September with parts of the country possibly touching 30C (86F) next weekend.A late warm spell could herald the start of a long, hot Indian Summer with freakish warmth threatening to hold out until December.Britons have been urged to wrap up over the next few nights with temperatures set to widely drop to single figures.However much of the country can look forward to clear sunny skies with &lsquohardly a breath of wind&rsquo to dampen spirits.UK weather forecast: Heatwave to hit Britain in September (Image: Netweather)UK weather forecast: Temperatures will begin to rise after the weekend (Image: Netweather)Met Office meteorologist Luke Miall said: &ldquoFriday is looking largely dry although there may be some showers across western parts of the country.&ldquoOver the weekend for much of England, Wales and eastern Scotland the weather is looking pretty decent with plenty of sunny spells and temperatures rising to around 24C (75F) which is above average for the start of September.&ldquoTemperatures are expected to creep up on Sunday with high pressure building and with some warm air coming up from the south we could see highs of 26C (78.8F) next week.&ldquoThe trend is for the Azores high to build through the start of September, so it will be quite pleasant with plenty of sunshine although there will be some chilly nights.&ldquoAhead of the weekend it will be largely dry with barely a breath of wind although we could see temperatures dip close to freezing in rural areas bringing a grass frost.UK weather charts show temperatures hitting 28C (82.4F) in parts of the south next week with highs of 22C (71F) forecast even for the far north.Southern Britain is expected to touch 24C (75F) this weekend with Scotland and northern England cooler between 15C (59F) and 22C (71.6F).UK weather forecast map: Hot temperatures to hit next week (Image: Netweather)Autumn is showing signs of following the trend set by summer bringing lashings of sunshine and unusually high temperatures.Thermometers could even touch the 30C (86F) mark between now and the end of the season if conditions are right, according to some experts.Exacta Weather&rsquos James Madden said: &ldquoWe could see temperatures surging towards 30C (86F) or possibly slightly higher during the start of September.&ldquoWarmer weather could persist for several days and while there will be some interruptions with cooler more unsettled spells, this trend could hold out through the month.&ldquoThere are early indications that temperatures will remain largely above average into October and possibly towards the middle of the month although there may be a transition to cooer conditions through the second half of autumn.John Hammond, meteorologist for Weathertrending, said daytime temperatures will take leap next week although chilly nights lay ahead.He said: &ldquoCompared with a cool late August, the first full week of September will probably see temperatures bounce back up again by day however, the lengthening nights will turn chilly. story: The next few days will be damp and dull (Image: MET OFFICE &amp )A CHILLY and misty start to Friday morning, including &ldquoa touch of air frost across some Scottish glens, will be followed by &ldquodull and damp weather in the days to come, according to the Met Office.Temperatures will rise from single digits to highs of around 20 degrees over the day, according to meteorologist Aidan McGivern.He stated: &ldquoA chilly start to Friday and a few mist patches first thing in southern parts of Britain and eastern England, western parts of Northern Ireland as well.&ldquoAlthough the breeze will quite quickly clear that mist and we will see thicker cloud rolling in by the end of the afternoon.                UK HOT weather forecast: Britain braces for post-weekend HEATWAVE                UK Weather forecast: Soaring temperatures to ENFULF UK next week&ldquoOtherwise, the cloud is bubbling up again with one or two showers in the south-east - I couldn&rsquot rule out the odd shower elsewhere as well.&ldquoBut, for most, it&rsquos a dry and bright Friday afternoon - and it's warmer.Mr McGivern commented the weather is warmer across the board - low 20s from the far north of Scotland right down to the south-east of England.By 3pm London will be experiencing 23 degrees, Birmingham 21 degrees, Glasgow 20 degrees and Aberdeen 16 degrees. Saturday will see the return of damp conditions after the bright Friday afternoon (Image: )The meteorologist added: &ldquoThe thicker cloud we see later on Friday into the far west will push its way further eastwards through Friday night.&ldquoIt&rsquos all tied in with this weather front which runs into an area of high pressure, so it does tend to weaken.Saturday will see the return of damp conditions after the bright Friday afternoon.Mr McGivern said: &ldquoA lot of humidity in this weather front will bring low misty cloud over much of Scotland to these Irish Sea coastal areas, Northern Ireland, western parts of Wales and Cornwall through Saturday.&ldquoSo a dull and damp day in places here. No significant rainfall but it will be fairly dreary across the western hills of Scotland in particular.&ldquoFurther east - much brighter skies! Sunny spells for central and eastern England and temperatures on the rise.He concluded Saturday temperatures will be looking at low to mid-20s in the south-east, but a little cooler in parts of Scotland and western areas of Britain.Sunday looks to be an improvement, with the sun coming out and temperatures hovering around the mid-20s.

title: Mystery Jesus turning water to wine archeologists discovery israel world
story: For hundreds of years, pilgrims have believed the site of the miracle to be Kafr Kanna, a town in northern Israel, where they visit the 20th-century Wedding Church.But the true location has long been debated &ndash and now archaeologists believe the Cana of biblical times may be a dusty hillside five miles further north.It&rsquos the former site of Khirbet Qana, a Jewish village between the years of 323BC and AD 324, where archaeologists have discovered a number of compelling clues.Excavations there have revealed a network of tunnels used for Christian worship, marked with crosses and references to Kyrie Iesou, a Greek phrase meaning Lord Jesus.                Jesus Christ or not the man suffered EXTREME TORTURE says study                LIFE AFTER DEATH: Woman &lsquomeets&rsquo Jesus and God in AFTERLIFEThere was also an altar and a shelf with the remains of a stone vessel, plus room for five more.Six stone jars like this held the wine in the biblical account of the miracle.Dr Tom McCollough, who directs excavations at the site, said there were three other sites with a credible claim to being the Cana of scripture.&ldquoBut none has the ensemble of evidence that makes such a persuasive case for Khirbet Qana, he said.Archaeologists believe the Cana could be the place of the miracle  (Image: Penmedia )There was also an altar and a shelf with the remains of a stone vessel (Image: Penmedia)&ldquoWe have uncovered a large Christian veneration cave complex that was used by Christian pilgrims who came to venerate the water-to-wine miracle.&ldquoThis complex was used beginning in the late fifth or early sixth century and continued to be used by pilgrims into the 12th-century Crusader period.&ldquoThe pilgrim texts we have from this period that describe what pilgrims did and saw when they came to Cana of Galilee match very closely what we have exposed as the veneration complex.As part of his evidence, Dr McCollough points to the work of first-century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus.He said: &ldquoHis references to Cana align geographically with the location of Khirbet Qana and align logically with his movements.                Life after death: Man claims to meet JESUS in afterlife&ldquoThe reference to Cana in Josephus, the New Testament and in the rabbinic texts would argue the village was a Jewish village, near the Sea of Galilee and in the region of lower Galilee.&ldquoKhirbet Qana fulfills all of these criteria.As for the better-known site at Kafr Kanna, Dr McCollough is sceptical.&ldquoWhen tourists visiting Israel today are taken to Cana, they are taken to Kafr Kanna, he said.&ldquoHowever, this site was not recognised as a pilgrimage site for those seeking Cana until the 1700s.It&rsquos the former site of Khirbet Qana, a Jewish village between the years of 323BC and AD 324 (Image: penmedia)&ldquoAt this point the Franciscans were managing Christian pilgrimage and facilitating easy passage rather than historical accuracy.Dr McCollough believes the discoveries at Khirbet Qana could even bolster the case for the historicity of the Gospel of John.He said: &ldquoOur excavations have shown that this was in fact a thriving Jewish village located in the heart of much of Jesus&rsquos life and ministry.&ldquoFor the Gospel of John, Cana is in some ways, Jesus&rsquos safe place or operational centre. It is a place He and His disciples return to when they encounter resistance in Judea.&ldquoI would argue our excavations warrant at least a reconsideration of the historical value of John&rsquos references to Cana and Jesus.

title: the sun says theresa may trade deals africa
story: A major factor of the Leave vote was for Britain to become an independent nation, free to strike global trade deals with fast-growing, emerging economies.So the Prime Minister is absolutely right to start outlining trade policy with our Commonwealth allies South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya.She is also right to call for funds from our bloated foreign aid budget to be diverted from frivolous handouts and used instead on developing infrastructure and security in Africa.As we unshackle ourselves from Brussels, it is clear Africa presents us with huge opportunities.It is the world’s second biggest continent, home to 16 per cent of the global population. Its GDP is growing rapidly. Similar to India, its middle classes are rocketing. And its workforce is estimated to be larger than China’s by 2035.Over 17 millions Brits voted for a Brexit that would make us a freer, richer country.This is exactly the type of buccaneering move that will make that vision a reality.THE EU’s threats regarding a No Deal Brexit are total bluster.The bloc claims there will be chaos if we leave without a deal, that the impact on trade and travel will be so severe we will crawl back to the negotiating table.But behind closed doors, the EU admits this is codswallop.The EU Commission has drawn up secret No Deal plans that are “very similar” to Britain’s Brexit preparation.In other words, in the event of a No Deal they will keep things almost exactly the same because they don’t want to be hit.What a surprise.WHEN will Labour moderates realise their party is beyond repair?Jewish Labour MPs need bodyguards for the party conference next month. There is a backlog of anti-Semitism complaints that could take YEARS to probe. And their leader is an ­anti-Semitic IRA-apologist, who counts the former BNP leader and the KKK among his cheerleaders.By staying in the party, Labour MPs signal that they want Corbyn to be PM.No amount of tribal loyalty can make them think that is a good idea.IT is shocking that deadly diet pills are being brazenly flogged on Instagram.The Facebook-owned company must better protect youngsters.It should hire a proper workforce to establish oversight of what is put online.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jehovahs witnesses
story: “Olympia doesn’t celebrate birthdays,” the 36-year-old said. “We’re Jehovah’s Witnesses, we don’t do that.”While for most of us our knowledge of Jehovahs Witnesses is their frequent door-knocking to try and convert you, a surprising number of celebs - including Serenas sister Venus and model Naomi Campbell - are followers or were raised in the faith.And there are unusual rules members have to follow: they cant have life-saving blood transfusions, are unable to vote or date without chaperones being present - and are forbidden from having oral sex both in and out of marriage.Serena and sister Venus were raised as Jehovahs Witnesses by their mother Oracene Price, who converted to the religion in the 1980s.Serena has been more outspoken about the religion - which was started in the 1870s in the US - constantly thanking Jehovah God for her success as a tennis player.In a recent Vogue interview she also said: Being a Jehovah’s Witness is important to me, but I’ve never really practiced it and have been wanting to get into it.Alexis [Serenas husband] didn’t grow up going to any church, but he’s really receptive and even takes the lead. He puts my needs first.”Legendary singer Prince, who passed away in April 2016, converted to the faith in 2001 following the death of his mother.He described his conversion as: a realisation. Its like Morpheus and Neo in The Matrix.A committed Jehovahs Witness to the end, a memorial for the star took place at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovahs Witnesses near his Minnesota home to commemorate his life.Canadian model Coco Rocha has opened up about her life as a devout Jehovahs Witness saying: faith is everything and despite her fame, she still preaches door-to-door.The whole purpose is to inform people. Some people think we’re a pushy religion, but if you’re not interested, just say so, she explained to luxury magazine Dujour.Naomi Campbells mum Valerie is also a follower, telling Vogue: I brought up Naomi as a Jehovahs Witness, but she must choose her faith for herself. I do give her literature on the subject though when she asks for it.However, the model has not followed in her mothers footsteps by becoming a believer.Other A-list celebs, including Janet Jackson, Ja Rule and actress Michelle Rodriguez were raised in the faith as children, but no longer practise it.Members follow their own version of the Bible called the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures.They say our world now belongs to Satan, and because of this God  - who they call Jehovah - will end it very soon in order to create a new kingdom.Jehovahs Witnesses are not meant to make friends with people of other faiths, as non-believers are considered to belong to Satans world - although this isnt always strict as their celebrity followers show.Many followers say there is a a sense of community that can come with being a Jehovahs Witness - as they are tight-knit and have respect for each other.The easy-to-follow belief system is also a big draw for people interested in the faith, and the organisation has a lot of literature providing what they believe to be the answers to lifes big questions.A Jehovahs Witness church: followers of the faith reject blood transfusions as they are seen as sinfulJehovahs Witnesses are barred from having blood transfusions - which makes operations like Caesarean sections - that often require them - more difficult to complete, as blood products are linked to immorality.As one Jehovahs Witness told the New Yorker: It’s as much a sin to take a blood transfusion as to have an extramarital affair.This has led to several deaths - and ious court battles between Jehovahs Witnesses and doctors seeking to treat them.Last Autumn, a 27-year-old Canadian new mother, Éloïse Dupuis, died a week after giving birth due to haemorrhaging - but despite doctors pleas for her to have a blood transfusion she refused.Jehovahs Witnesses dont believe in sex before marriage - and dating isnt condoned unless they bring along a chaperone as well.So its likely that the first person you choose to date will be the person you marry.And after marriage, theres still restrictions on sex - namely anal and oral sex which are strictly forbidden, something that is also frowned upon in religions such as Islam and other forms of Christianity.Followers are peaceful - even refusing military service - but are suffering from persecution in some countries.Earlier this year, they were declared as an extremist group in Russia with raids on their churches and several arrests - its thought hundreds have fled the country and applied for asylum in Finland since.Other things they are prohibited from doing include being patriotic, as it is seen as worshipping an idol, or voting or canvassing for political parties as they remain politically neutral.As Jesus never celebrated his birthday, Jehovahs Witnesses dont mark theirs either, and they dont acknowledge the major Christian holidays of Christmas Day or Easter, as they believe these festivals are based on pagan customs.On the plus side, it means they probably save a lot of money due to not having to fork out for expensive gifts.Their beliefs in the end of the world have led to a series of unfulfilled prophecies.In 1975 they were told the world would end and members of the church were encouraged to preach full-time and get rid of their possessions.Thousands of them quit their jobs and sold their homes - but Armageddon didnt come leading to a drop in membership, something which has remained in decline ever since.Armageddon was also promised before the start of the Millennium, but again never materialised.There has also been other controversies: the Charity Commission are currently investigating claims that some followers were abused as children by fellow members of the faith.Members are known for their recruitment drives: previously, they would go door-to-door to try and recruit new converts, handing out literature that explains their beliefs.However, people who have left the church have described this as being exhausting.One said: I barely got any sleep when I was a Witness...I needed the weekends to catch up on my sleep debt, but instead I had to get up at the crack of dawn to go out preaching.Followers of the religion are now more commonly found preaching outside train stations across the UK, and in London alone their volunteers give out an estimated 100,000 magazines every month.The publication, Awake!, has been running since 1919, and with a global circulation of 65 million they show no sign of stopping recruiting any time soon. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
